an6.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an6.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an6.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an6.1:2.1.pli: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an6.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an6.1:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
an6.1:2.3.eng: It’s a mendicant who, when they see a sight with their eyes, is neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

an6.1:2.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an6.1:2.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an6.1:2.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an6.1:2.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an6.1:2.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya neva sumano hoti na dummano, upekkhako viharati sato sampajāno.
an6.1:2.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they’re neither happy nor sad. They remain equanimous, mindful and aware.

an6.1:2.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an6.1:2.9.eng: A mendicant with these six qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an6.1:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an6.1:3.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an6.1:3.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an6.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
an6.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

an6.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno, kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.10:1.2.eng: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an6.10:1.3.pli: “yo so, bhante, ariyasāvako āgataphalo viññātasāsano, so katamena vihārena bahulaṃ viharatī”ti?
an6.10:1.3.eng: “Sir, when a noble disciple has reached the fruit and understood the instructions, what kind of meditation do they frequently practice?”

an6.10:2.1.pli: “Yo so, mahānāma, ariyasāvako āgataphalo viññātasāsano, so iminā vihārena bahulaṃ viharati.
an6.10:2.1.eng: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple has reached the fruit and understood the instructions they frequently practice this kind of meditation.

an6.10:2.2.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple recollects the Realized One:

an6.10:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an6.10:2.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an6.10:2.4.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:2.4.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the Realized One their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.10:2.5.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti tathāgataṃ ārabbha.
an6.10:2.5.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the Realized One.

an6.10:2.6.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an6.10:2.6.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an6.10:2.7.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an6.10:2.7.eng: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an6.10:2.9.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno buddhānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:2.9.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of the Buddha.

an6.10:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako dhammaṃ anussarati:
an6.10:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple recollects the teaching:

an6.10:3.2.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
an6.10:3.2.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

an6.10:3.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako dhammaṃ anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:3.3.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the teaching their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an6.10:3.4.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti dhammaṃ ārabbha.

an6.10:3.5.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an6.10:3.6.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an6.10:3.8.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno dhammānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:3.8.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of the teaching.

an6.10:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako saṅghaṃ anussarati:
an6.10:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple recollects the Saṅgha:

an6.10:4.2.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
an6.10:4.2.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

an6.10:4.3.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako saṅghaṃ anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:4.3.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the Saṅgha their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an6.10:4.4.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti saṅghaṃ ārabbha.

an6.10:4.5.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an6.10:4.6.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an6.10:4.8.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno saṅghānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:4.8.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of the Saṅgha.

an6.10:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako attano sīlāni anussarati akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
an6.10:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple recollects their own ethical conduct, which is intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.

an6.10:5.2.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako sīlaṃ anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:5.2.eng: When a noble disciple recollects their ethical conduct their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an6.10:5.3.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti sīlaṃ ārabbha.

an6.10:5.4.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an6.10:5.5.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an6.10:5.7.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno sīlānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:5.7.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of ethics.

an6.10:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako attano cāgaṃ anussarati:
an6.10:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple recollects their own generosity:

an6.10:6.3.pli: Yohaṃ maccheramalapariyuṭṭhitāya pajāya vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasāmi muttacāgo payatapāṇi vosaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato’ti.
an6.10:6.3.eng: Among people full of the stain of stinginess I live at home rid of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.’

an6.10:6.4.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako cāgaṃ anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:6.4.eng: When a noble disciple recollects their own generosity their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion. …

an6.10:6.5.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti cāgaṃ ārabbha.

an6.10:6.6.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.

an6.10:6.7.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.

an6.10:6.9.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno cāgānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:6.9.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of generosity.

an6.10:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, mahānāma, ariyasāvako devatānussatiṃ bhāveti:
an6.10:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple recollects the deities:

an6.10:7.2.pli: ‘santi devā cātumahārājikā, santi devā tāvatiṃsā, santi devā yāmā, santi devā tusitā, santi devā nimmānaratino, santi devā paranimmitavasavattino, santi devā brahmakāyikā, santi devā tatuttari.
an6.10:7.2.eng: ‘There are the gods of the four great kings, the gods of the thirty-three, the gods of Yama, the joyful gods, the gods who love to create, the gods who control what is created by others, the gods of the Divinity’s host, and gods even higher than these.

an6.10:7.3.pli: Yathārūpāya saddhāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā saṃvijjati.
an6.10:7.3.eng: When those deities passed away from here, they were reborn there because of their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom. I, too, have the same kind of faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.’

an6.10:7.4.pli: Yathārūpena sīlena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sīlaṃ saṃvijjati.

an6.10:7.5.pli: Yathārūpena sutena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpaṃ sutaṃ saṃvijjati.

an6.10:7.6.pli: Yathārūpena cāgena samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpo cāgo saṃvijjati.

an6.10:7.7.pli: Yathārūpāya paññāya samannāgatā tā devatā ito cutā tattha upapannā, mayhampi tathārūpā paññā saṃvijjatī’ti.

an6.10:7.8.pli: Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako attano ca tāsañca devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañca sutañca cāgañca paññañca anussarati nevassa tasmiṃ samaye rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti;
an6.10:7.8.eng: When a noble disciple recollects the faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom of both themselves and the deities their mind is not full of greed, hate, and delusion.

an6.10:7.9.pli: ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hoti tā devatā ārabbha.
an6.10:7.9.eng: At that time their mind is quite unswerving, based on the deities.

an6.10:7.10.pli: Ujugatacitto kho pana, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ, labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ.
an6.10:7.10.eng: A noble disciple whose mind is unswerving finds inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and finds joy connected with the teaching.

an6.10:7.11.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
an6.10:7.11.eng: When you’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, you feel bliss. And when you’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

an6.10:7.13.pli: ‘ariyasāvako visamagatāya pajāya samappatto viharati, sabyāpajjāya pajāya abyāpajjo viharati, dhammasotaṃ samāpanno devatānussatiṃ bhāveti’.
an6.10:7.13.eng: a noble disciple who lives in balance among people who are unbalanced, and lives untroubled among people who are troubled. They’ve entered the stream of the teaching and develop the recollection of the deities.

an6.10:8.1.pli: Yo so, mahānāma, ariyasāvako āgataphalo viññātasāsano, so iminā vihārena bahulaṃ viharatī”ti.
an6.10:8.1.eng: When a noble disciple has reached the fruit and understood the instructions this is the kind of meditation they frequently practice.”

an6.100:1.1.pli: “So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kañci dhammaṃ attato samanupassanto …pe…
an6.100:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is quite impossible for a mendicant who regards any condition as self to accept views that agree with the teaching. …

an6.100:1.2.eng: It’s quite possible for a mendicant who regards all things as not-self to accept views that agree with the teaching. …”

an6.101:1.1.pli: “‘So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nibbānaṃ dukkhato samanupassanto anulomikāya khantiyā samannāgato bhavissatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an6.101:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is quite impossible for a mendicant who regards extinguishment as suffering to accept views that conform with the teaching. …

an6.101:1.2.pli: ‘Anulomikāya khantiyā asamannāgato sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamissatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

an6.101:1.3.pli: ‘Sammattaniyāmaṃ anokkamamāno sotāpattiphalaṃ vā sakadāgāmiphalaṃ vā anāgāmiphalaṃ vā arahattaṃ vā sacchikarissatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.

an6.101:2.1.pli: ‘So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nibbānaṃ sukhato samanupassanto anulomikāya khantiyā samannāgato bhavissatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an6.101:2.1.eng: It’s quite possible for a mendicant who regards extinguishment as pleasurable to accept views that conform with the teaching. …”

an6.101:2.2.pli: ‘Anulomikāya khantiyā samannāgato sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamissatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.

an6.101:2.3.pli: ‘Sammattaniyāmaṃ okkamamāno sotāpattiphalaṃ vā sakadāgāmiphalaṃ vā anāgāmiphalaṃ vā arahattaṃ vā sacchikarissatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjatī”ti.

an6.102:1.1.pli: “Cha, bhikkhave, ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbasaṅkhāresu anodhiṃ karitvā aniccasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetuṃ.
an6.102:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, seeing six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of impermanence in all conditions without qualification.

an6.102:1.3.pli: ‘Sabbasaṅkhārā ca me anavatthitā khāyissanti, sabbaloke ca me mano nābhiramissati, sabbalokā ca me mano vuṭṭhahissati, nibbānapoṇañca me mānasaṃ bhavissati, saṃyojanā ca me pahānaṃ gacchissanti, paramena ca sāmaññena samannāgato bhavissāmī’ti.
an6.102:1.3.eng: ‘All conditions will appear to me as transient.’ ‘My mind will not delight anywhere in the world.’ ‘My mind will rise above the whole world.’ ‘My heart will incline to extinguishment.’ ‘My fetters will be given up.’ ‘I will achieve the ultimate goal of the ascetic life.’

an6.102:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbasaṅkhāresu anodhiṃ karitvā aniccasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetun”ti.
an6.102:1.4.eng: Seeing these six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of impermanence in all conditions without qualification.”

an6.103:1.1.pli: “Cha, bhikkhave, ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbasaṅkhāresu anodhiṃ karitvā dukkhasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetuṃ.
an6.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, seeing six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of suffering in all conditions without qualification.

an6.103:1.3.pli: ‘Sabbasaṅkhāresu ca me nibbidasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā bhavissati, seyyathāpi ukkhittāsike vadhake.
an6.103:1.3.eng: ‘Perception of disillusionment will be established in me for all conditions, like a killer with a drawn sword.’

an6.103:1.4.pli: Sabbalokā ca me mano vuṭṭhahissati, nibbāne ca santadassāvī bhavissāmi, anusayā ca me samugghātaṃ gacchissanti, kiccakārī ca bhavissāmi, satthā ca me pariciṇṇo bhavissati mettāvatāyā’ti.
an6.103:1.4.eng: ‘My mind will rise above the whole world.’ ‘I will see extinguishment as peaceful.’ ‘My underlying tendencies will be uprooted.’ ‘I will fulfill my duty.’ ‘I will have served my Teacher with love.’

an6.103:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbasaṅkhāresu anodhiṃ karitvā dukkhasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetun”ti.
an6.103:1.5.eng: Seeing these six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of suffering in all conditions without qualification.”

an6.104:1.1.pli: “Cha, bhikkhave, ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbadhammesu anodhiṃ karitvā anattasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetuṃ.
an6.104:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, seeing six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of not-self in all things without qualification.

an6.104:1.3.pli: Sabbaloke ca atammayo bhavissāmi, ahaṅkārā ca me uparujjhissanti, mamaṅkārā ca me uparujjhissanti, asādhāraṇena ca ñāṇena samannāgato bhavissāmi, hetu ca me sudiṭṭho bhavissati, hetusamuppannā ca dhammā.
an6.104:1.3.eng: ‘I will not be determined by anything in the world.’ ‘My I-making will stop.’ ‘My mine-making will stop.’ ‘I will have distinct knowledge.’ ‘I will clearly see causes and the phenomena that arise from causes.’

an6.104:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha ānisaṃse sampassamānena alameva bhikkhunā sabbadhammesu anodhiṃ karitvā anattasaññaṃ upaṭṭhāpetun”ti.
an6.104:1.4.eng: Seeing these six benefits is quite enough to establish the perception of not-self in all things without qualification.”

an6.105:1.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, bhavā pahātabbā, tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhitabbaṃ.
an6.105:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up these three states of existence. And you should train in three trainings.

an6.105:1.2.eng: What are the three states of existence you should give up?

an6.105:1.3.eng: Existence in the sensual realm, the realm of luminous form, and the formless realm.

an6.105:1.4.eng: These are the three states of existence you should give up.

an6.105:1.5.eng: What are the three trainings you should train in?

an6.105:1.6.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an6.105:1.7.eng: These are the three trainings you should train in.

an6.105:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ime tayo bhavā pahīnā honti, imāsu ca tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhitasikkho hoti—
an6.105:1.8.eng: When a mendicant has given up these three states of existence and has trained in these three trainings

an6.105:1.9.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”ti.
an6.105:1.9.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”

an6.106:1.1.pli: “Tisso imā, bhikkhave, taṇhā pahātabbā, tayo ca mānā.
an6.106:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up these three cravings and three conceits.

an6.106:1.2.eng: What three cravings should you give up?

an6.106:1.3.eng: Craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

an6.106:1.4.eng: These are the three cravings you should give up.

an6.106:1.5.eng: What three conceits should you give up?

an6.106:1.6.eng: Conceit, inferiority complex, and superiority complex.

an6.106:1.7.eng: These are the three conceits you should give up.

an6.106:1.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno imā tisso taṇhā pahīnā honti, ime ca tayo mānā;
an6.106:1.8.eng: When a mendicant has given up these three cravings and these three conceits

an6.106:1.9.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”ti.
an6.106:1.9.eng: they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”

an6.107:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.107:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.107:1.7.pli: Rāgassa pahānāya asubhā bhāvetabbā, dosassa pahānāya mettā bhāvetabbā, mohassa pahānāya paññā bhāvetabbā.
an6.107:1.7.eng: You should develop the perception of ugliness to give up greed, love to give up hate, and wisdom to give up delusion.

an6.107:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.107:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.108:1.3.eng: Bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an6.108:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.108:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.108:1.7.pli: Kāyaduccaritassa pahānāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ, vacīduccaritassa pahānāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ, manoduccaritassa pahānāya manosucaritaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ.
an6.108:1.7.eng: You should develop good bodily conduct to give up bad bodily conduct, good verbal conduct to give up bad verbal conduct, and good mental conduct to give up bad mental conduct.

an6.108:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.108:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.109:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.109:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.109:1.7.pli: Kāmavitakkassa pahānāya nekkhammavitakko bhāvetabbo, byāpādavitakkassa pahānāya abyāpādavitakko bhāvetabbo, vihiṃsāvitakkassa pahānāya avihiṃsāvitakko bhāvetabbo.
an6.109:1.7.eng: You should develop thoughts of renunciation to give up sensual thoughts, thoughts of good will to give up malicious thoughts, and thoughts of harmlessness to give up cruel thoughts.

an6.109:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.109:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.11:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these six warm-hearted qualities.

an6.11:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:1.3.eng: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private. This is a warm-hearted quality.

an6.11:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness, both in public and in private. This too is a warm-hearted quality.

an6.11:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhitaṃ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …

an6.11:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions. This too is a warm-hearted quality.

an6.11:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni tathārūpehi sīlehi sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion. This too is a warm-hearted quality.

an6.11:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo.
an6.11:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. This too is a warm-hearted quality.

an6.11:7.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha dhammā sāraṇīyā”ti.
an6.11:7.1.eng: These are the six warm-hearted qualities.”

an6.110:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.110:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.110:1.7.pli: Kāmasaññāya pahānāya nekkhammasaññā bhāvetabbā, byāpādasaññāya pahānāya abyāpādasaññā bhāvetabbā, vihiṃsāsaññāya pahānāya avihiṃsāsaññā bhāvetabbā.
an6.110:1.7.eng: You should develop perceptions of renunciation to give up sensual perceptions, perceptions of good will to give up malicious perceptions, and perceptions of harmlessness to give up cruel perceptions.

an6.110:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.110:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.111:1.3.eng: The elements of sensuality, malice, and cruelty.

an6.111:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.111:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.111:1.7.pli: Kāmadhātuyā pahānāya nekkhammadhātu bhāvetabbā, byāpādadhātuyā pahānāya abyāpādadhātu bhāvetabbā, vihiṃsādhātuyā pahānāya avihiṃsādhātu bhāvetabbā.
an6.111:1.7.eng: You should develop the element of renunciation to give up the element of sensuality, the element of good will to give up the element of malice, and the element of harmlessness to give up the element of cruelty.

an6.111:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.111:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.112:1.3.eng: The view that things are gratifying, the theory of self, and wrong view.

an6.112:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.112:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.112:1.7.pli: Assādadiṭṭhiyā pahānāya aniccasaññā bhāvetabbā, attānudiṭṭhiyā pahānāya anattasaññā bhāvetabbā, micchādiṭṭhiyā pahānāya sammādiṭṭhi bhāvetabbā.
an6.112:1.7.eng: You should develop the perception of impermanence to give up the view that things are gratifying; the perception of not-self to give up the theory of self; and right view to give up wrong view.

an6.112:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.112:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”

an6.113:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā.
an6.113:1.5.eng: To give up these three things you should develop three things.

an6.113:1.7.pli: Aratiyā pahānāya muditā bhāvetabbā, vihiṃsāya pahānāya avihiṃsā bhāvetabbā, adhammacariyāya pahānāya dhammacariyā bhāvetabbā.
an6.113:1.7.eng: You should develop rejoicing to give up discontent, harmlessness to give up cruelty, and principled conduct to give up unprincipled conduct.

an6.113:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an6.113:1.8.eng: These are the three things you should develop to give up those three things.”
